qas.question: What view did Peirce think had been driven to excess?
Who formed the basis for modern scientific method?
When did Pierce begin to take excesses with data-driven empiricism?

plausible_answers.text: Peirce severely criticized many elements of Descartes' peculiar brand of rationalism

qas.question: Which philosopher did Pierce agree with the most?
When was the strict-empiricist view started?

plausible_answers.text: to counterbalance the excesses to which some of his cohorts had taken

qas.question: Why did Pierce prefer the data-driven empiricist view?

context: <a3_0>Charles Peirce<a3_0/> (<a0_0>1839<a0_0/>–<a1_0><b8_0>1914<b8_0/><a1_0/>) was highly influential in laying the groundwork for today's empirical scientific method.[citation needed] Although <b6_0>Peirce severely criticized many elements of <a4_0><b7_0>Descartes<b7_0/><a4_0/>' peculiar brand of rationalism<b6_0/>, he did not reject rationalism outright. Indeed, he concurred with the main ideas of rationalism, most importantly the idea that rational concepts can be meaningful and the idea that rational concepts necessarily go beyond the data given by empirical observation. <b5_0>In later years<b5_0/> he even emphasized the concept-driven side of the then ongoing debate between strict empiricism and strict rationalism, in part <b9_0>to counterbalance the excesses to which some of his cohorts had taken<b9_0/> pragmatism under <a2_0>the "data-driven" strict-empiricist view<a2_0/>.
